questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with progressive muscle weakness, atrophy, and fasciculations. He is diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Which of the following is true about ALS?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)/Lou Gehrig’s Disease:

  • It is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that selectively targets motor neurons.
  • Superoxide dismutase deficiency: Mutations in the SOD1 gene result in the accumulation of reactive oxygen species, which damage the anterior horn cells. (Option A)
  • Glutamate excitotoxicity: Excessive glutamate receptor activation leads to overexcitation and death of motor neurons. (Option B)
  • Target cells: The primary targets of this disease are the anterior horn cells (lower motor neurons) and the corticospinal tract neurons (upper motor neurons). (Option C)

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with a brainstem lesion shows impaired skilled hand movements but preserved posture and balance. Which descending tract is least concerned with proximal muscle movement and posture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The rubrospinal tract is part of the lateral motor system and primarily facilitates skilled, voluntary movements of distal limb muscles, especially those in the upper limbs. It does not significantly contribute to proximal muscle control or postural regulation.

Rubrospinal Tract:

  • Origin: Arises from the red nucleus in the midbrain tegmentum.
  • Decussation: Crosses to the contralateral side in the ventral tegmental decussation (caudal midbrain).
  • Inputs: Receives signals from the motor cortex and cerebellum.
  • Termination: Synapses in the ventral horn (laminae V, VI, VII) of the spinal cord.
  • Function:
    • Influences alpha and gamma motor neurons that stimulate flexor muscles.
    • Helps regulate muscle tone.
    • Coordinates rudimentary motor skills, refined further by the corticospinal tract.
    • Plays a role in hand and finger movements, especially flexor control.

Explanation of Other Options:

Tectospinal tract (Option B): The tectospinal tract is part of the medial motor system and contributes to reflex postural adjustments in response to auditory and visual stimuli.

Reticulospinal tract (Option C): This tract is part of the medial motor system and helps regulate reflex control and tone of proximal muscles.

Vestibulospinal tract (Option D): The vestibulospinal tract is also part of the medial motor system and plays an essential role in balance and posture by influencing proximal muscles.

References:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK554542/#

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a cortical lesion is being evaluated for motor deficits. Which statement about the motor homunculus is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Not all corticospinal and corticobulbar fibres arise solely from the motor cortex:

  • Only 30% of the fibres originate from the primary motor cortex (area 4).
  • Another 30% arise from the premotor and supplementary motor areas (area 6).
  • The remaining 40% originates from the parietal lobe, specifically from the somatosensory cortex (areas 3, 1, and 2).
    Thus, the tract arises from a distributed cortical motor system, not just the motor cortex alone.

The motor homunculus is a somatotopic map representing the cortical control of voluntary muscles:

  • It lies along the precentral gyrus.
  • The size of the cortical area dedicated to each body part is not based on the size of the body part, but rather on the precision and complexity of its movement.
  • Areas like the lips, tongue, fingers, and hands occupy a disproportionately large area. (Option B)
  • Muscles involved in speech and vocalisation (e.g., larynx, lips, pharynx) consume a large area due to their intricate motor control needs. (Option C)

Related Important Points:

  • The motor homunculus is arranged from medial to lateral: Leg → Trunk → Arm → Face → Tongue.
  • Cortical lesions cause contralateral motor deficits, often corresponding to the mapped body region.
  • The face and hand areas are particularly susceptible to small cortical strokes due to their dense representation of these regions.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with a stroke in the posterior parietal lobe has difficulty with purposeful movements. Which is true about this lesion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Lesions in the posterior parietal cortex often result in ideomotor or ideational apraxia, impairing the ability to perform learned, purposeful movement sequences (e.g., using utensils), despite having intact motor strength.
  • The posterior parietal lobe, specifically the somatosensory association cortex, plays a key role in motor control and coordination.
    • Projection to premotor cortex: Fibres from the posterior parietal cortex project to the premotor area, aiding in movement planning. (Option A)
    • Motor performance defects: Lesions in this region cause deficits in executing purposeful, learned movements (apraxia) even without motor weakness. (Option B)
    • Hand-eye coordination: Some neurons in this area are involved in coordinating visual information with motor actions, which is critical for hand-eye coordination and object manipulation. (Option C)

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a traumatic upper midbrain transection presents with extensor posturing. Which feature is most characteristic of this lesion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A complete transection at the upper midbrain level (around the level of the superior colliculus) results in decerebrate rigidity.

Decerebrate Rigidity:

  • Cause: Lesions at the midbrain level (especially around the superior colliculus) interrupt descending cortical and rubrospinal inputs.
  • Mechanism: Loss of inhibitory (flexor-promoting) signals from the corticospinal and rubrospinal tracts leads to unopposed activity of the vestibulospinal and reticulospinal (Option C ruled out)
  • Effect: This results in hyperactivity of extensor muscles in all four limbs, producing decerebrate rigidity. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presents to the emergency ward with severe headache and altered consciousness. A CT scan reveals a large mass in the temporal lobe producing uncal herniation. Which of the following features may be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In uncal herniation (medial temporal lobe herniation), the expanding mass compresses midbrain structures, which results in Cheyne-Stokes respiration.
  • This is a characteristic pattern of alternating deep and shallow breathing with periods of apnea.
  • Midbrain involvement: Direct compression leads to irregular respiratory patterns due to damage to the brainstem respiratory centres.
  • Pupils are typically dilated and fixed (due to 3rd cranial nerve compression), not constricted. (Option A, C ruled out)

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a lesion in the premotor cortex struggles with initiating movements. Which is true about the premotor cortex?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The premotor cortex is primarily responsible for postural adjustments and preparing the body for voluntary movements.
  • It is located in Brodmann area 6, involved in setting up posture at the start of a planned movement.
  • It integrates sensory input from the parietal cortex and helps coordinate complex, anticipatory motor activity by influencing:
    • Primary motor cortex (M1)
    • Brainstem reticular formation
    • Spinal cord

Explanation of Other Options:

The Premotor cortex receives input from the primary motor cortex (Option A): Because the premotor cortex receives input from sensory regions of the parietal cortex, not from the primary motor cortex. It projects to the primary motor cortex.

The Premotor cortex is involved in organising or planning the motor sequences (Option B): It is partially correct as the premotor cortex contributes to planning motor sequences, particularly for externally triggered movements, but the supplementary motor cortex plays a more dominant role in internally generated motor sequences.

In the premotor cortex, the cortical representation of each body part is proportional in size to the skill with which the part is used in fine, voluntary movement (Option C): This feature (the motor homunculus with proportional representation for fine control) is found in the primary motor cortex (M1), not the premotor cortex.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a spinal cord lesion affecting the ventral corticospinal tract has impaired posture. Which is true about this tract?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The ventral corticospinal tract mainly controls proximal and axial muscles responsible for maintaining posture and balance.
  • The ventral corticospinal tract consists of about 20% of corticospinal fibres that do not decussate at the medulla (pyramidal decussation). (Option A, C ruled out)
  • These fibres descend in the anterior funiculus of the spinal cord and control proximal muscles of the limbs, trunk, and neck involved in posture and balance.
  • They help stabilise the body during movement and support the activity of the lateral corticospinal tract.

questions.solution:
Explanation:

The vestibulospinal tract plays a crucial role in maintaining balance and muscle tone in postural muscles.

Vestibulospinal Tract:

Explanation of Other Options:

Corticobulbar tract (Option A): This tract controls conscious, voluntary movements of head, face, and neck muscles, not postural control.

Rubrospinal tract (Option C): This tract primarily influences upper limb flexor muscle tone and movement, not posture and balance.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with a left leg amputation experiences persistent phantom limb pain. Which treatment is most effective?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Spinal cord stimulation works by sending mild electrical signals to the spinal cord, which modulates pain pathways and provides relief from phantom limb pain.
  • In spinal cord stimulation, an electrode is placed near the spinal cord to deliver controlled electrical impulses.
  • This reduces pain signals reaching the brain while causing a tingling sensation in the area where the limb used to be.
  • It's particularly effective in chronic phantom limb pain seen months to years after amputation.

Explanation of Other Options:

Epidural anaesthesia (Option A): While it helps in acute perioperative pain during amputation surgery, it does not relieve chronic phantom limb pain experienced long after the surgery.

High-dose Corticosteroids (Option C): High-dose corticosteroids are used for acute inflammation, not for chronic neuropathic pain such as phantom limb pain, which involves central and peripheral sensitisation.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man with a T5 spinal cord hemisection presents with Brown-Séquard syndrome. What motor feature is seen in the ipsilateral lower limb?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In Brown-Sequard syndrome, motor pathways (corticospinal tract) below the lesion are disrupted, resulting in upper motor neuron signs like hypertonia and spastic paralysis in the ipsilateral lower limb.

Brown-Sequard Syndrome:

  • Involves hemisection of the spinal cord.
  • Below the lesion (T5), corticospinal tract fibres (UMN) are damaged on the same side (ipsilateral), leading to:
    • Spastic paralysis (hypertonia)
    • Increased deep tendon reflexes
    • Positive Babinski sign

Related Important Points:

  • Ipsilateral UMN signs below lesion → due to corticospinal tract damage
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature → due to spinothalamic tract decussating at spinal level
  • Ipsilateral loss of proprioception and fine touch → due to dorsal column involvement

Explanation of Other Options:

Lost deep tendon reflexes (Option A):
Reflexes are typically increased below the lesion in UMN damage. However, at the level of the lesion (T5), reflexes may be lost only segmentally due to anterior horn or nerve root involvement.

Flaccid type of paralysis (Option B):
 Seen at the level of lesion due to LMN involvement. However, in the lower limb, which is below T5, corticospinal damage causes spastic (not flaccid) paralysis.

Disuse atrophy (Option D):
 Though mild disuse atrophy may develop over time in UMN lesions, the hallmark early feature is hyperreflexia and hypertonia, not atrophy. LMN lesions cause rapid, severe muscle wasting, especially at the level of the lesion.

Key Takeaway:
Brown-Sequard syndrome at the T5 level produces ipsilateral UMN signs (hypertonia, spastic paralysis) below the lesion due to loss of descending corticospinal fibres.

questions.text: A 40-year-old with an upper cervical spinal cord transection presents with hypotension and absent reflexes. Which features characterise spinal shock?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Spinal shock causes temporary cessation of all spinal cord functions below the level of transection, including motor, sensory, reflex, and autonomic control. (Option B)
  • Sudden complete transection of the spinal cord results in immediate loss of all reflex activity, hypotension, and autonomic dysfunction, including bladder areflexia. (Option A)
  • These features define the acute phase of spinal shock, which may last for 1-2 weeks before the gradual return of reflexes (sometimes hyperactive due to loss of supraspinal inhibition).
  • Sympathetic tone is lost below the lesion level, leading to vasodilation and hypotension, especially in high cervical transections.
  • All somatic reflexes are abolished during the acute phase due to the temporary loss of excitability of spinal circuits.
  • Autonomic bladder control is lost, leading to retention followed by overflow incontinence. (Option C)

Key Takeaway:

Features of Spinal Shock: (Mnemonic: FLACCID)

  • F: Flaccidity
  • L: Loss of all reflexes
  • A: Autonomic dysfunction (overflow bladder)
  • C: Complete sensory loss
  • C: Cold extremities (↓ BP)
  • I: Involvement of all limbs below the lesion
  • D: Duration ~1-2 weeks

questions.text: A 30-year-old male visited a psychiatrist with psychological symptoms. He was diagnosed with schizophrenia and started on haloperidol. After 2 years of use, he developed involuntary movements of the face and cogwheel rigidity. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tardive dyskinesia (TD) is a late-onset extrapyramidal side effect caused by long-term neuroleptic use, especially typical antipsychotics like haloperidol.

  • Tardive Dyskinesia (TD):
  • Caused by chronic dopamine receptor blockade, which leads to dopaminergic hypersensitivity in the nigrostriatal pathway.
  • Common features include involuntary movements of the face, tongue, and lips, often described as lip-smacking, grimacing, or tongue thrusting.
  • Rigidity (like cogwheel rigidity) may also be present due to chronic dopamine receptor blockade, reflecting basal ganglia dysfunction.

Explanation of Other Options:

Parkinson's disease (Option A): Parkinsonism involves degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra, not drug-induced dopamine receptor supersensitivity.

Huntington's chorea (Option B): Huntington's is a genetic disorder (CAG repeats), affecting the caudate nucleus, characterised by choreiform movements and cognitive decline.

Wilson's disease (Option D): Wilson's disease is due to copper accumulation and affects the liver and basal ganglia, but is not typically associated with chronic neuroleptic use.

Key Takeaway:

Tardive dyskinesia (TD) results from long-term use of dopamine-blocking drugs, such as haloperidol. It presents with involuntary, repetitive movements of the face, lips, and limbs.

questions.text: A 60-year-old with basal ganglia dysfunction is evaluated for motor deficits. Which statement about basal ganglia input fibres is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The principal neurotransmitter of basal ganglia input fibres (cortico-striatal and thalamo-striatal) is glutamate, not acetylcholine.

  • Basal ganglia receive excitatory glutamatergic inputs from the cerebral cortex and thalamus.
  • Input to the basal ganglia arrives via two main excitatory pathways:
    • Cortico-striatal fibres (from the cerebral cortex) (Option A)
    • Thalamo-striatal fibres (from the thalamus) (Option B)
  • Both these fibres release glutamate, which is an excitatory neurotransmitter. (Option D)
  • Acetylcholine, on the other hand, is released by large interneurons within the striatum, not by external input fibres.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male visited the doctor for difficulty in speaking, known as dysarthria. The doctor evaluated the patient and advised some investigations. After studying the reports doctor found that some part of the basal ganglia is damaged. Which nucleus is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lesions in the head of the left caudate nucleus are linked to dysarthric aphasia due to its role in regulating motor aspects of speech through frontal lobe connections.

  • The caudate nucleus is a part of the basal ganglia that plays a key role in cognitive and motor control, especially of speech.
  • The head of the caudate nucleus has strong connections with frontal cortical areas, particularly involved in motor speech planning.
  • Lesions in the left caudate nucleus, which is usually the dominant hemisphere, are associated with dysarthric aphasia (slurred speech with preserved language comprehension).
  • This is distinct from Broca's or Wernicke's aphasia; it results from subcortical damage affecting motor regulation, not language formation.

Explanation of other options:

Head of the Right caudate nucleus (Option A): Right-sided caudate lesions are not typically associated with speech disturbances.

Right subthalamic nucleus (Option C): The lesion causes hemiballismus, a violent, involuntary movement disorder.

Left putamen nucleus (Option D): Lesions in the left putamen nucleus are more associated with dystonia or Parkinsonian symptoms, not primarily dysarthria, which involves speech motor control.

Key takeaway:

  • Left caudate nucleus lesion → Dysarthria
  • Subthalamic nucleus lesion → Hemiballismus
  • Putamen nucleus lesion → Athetosis

questions.text: Which statement about the basal ganglia is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Basal ganglia lesions result in increased gamma efferent discharge and muscle spindle sensitivity, leading to hypertonia, not hypotonia.

Basal Ganglia:

  • Involved in the planning and execution of complex motor programs, especially automatic, learned motor behaviour. (Option A)
  • Plays a subconscious role in coordinated actions like arm swinging during walking and facial expressions. (Option B)
  • Lesions can lead to mask-like facies due to impaired facial muscle coordination (e.g., in Parkinson's disease). (Option D)
  • Regulates muscle tone by modulating gamma motor neurons and muscle spindle sensitivity.
  • Lesions cause hypertonia due to reduced inhibition of postural reflexes.
  • Also involved in reflex control and automatic movement patterns.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with a 10-year history of Parkinsonâ€™s disease had shown a good response to medical therapy until six months ago. Recently, he has developed a gradual decline in responsiveness to his medications. What alternative therapeutic option should now be considered?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

When patients with Parkinson's disease exhibit declining response to pharmacological therapy, especially after prolonged use of levodopa, advanced surgical or restorative interventions are considered to manage motor fluctuations and dyskinesias.

These include:

  • Deep Brain Stimulation (Option A):
    • Electrodes implanted in the subthalamic nucleus or globus pallidus interna
    • Provides reversible neuromodulation of abnormal basal ganglia output
    • Reduces motor fluctuations and L-dopa-induced dyskinesias
  • Subthalamic Nucleus Ablation (Option B):
    • Also referred to as pallidotomy or subthalamotomy
    • Involves creating a lesion to restore balance in the motor loop
    • Considered in tremor-dominant or medication-resistant cases
  • Focused Ultrasound Thalamotomy (Option C):
    • Non-invasive technique to ablate the ventral intermediate nucleus of thalamus
    • Especially effective in controlling tremor
    • Used in selected advanced Parkinson's cases where surgery is contraindicated

Related Important Points:

  • Initial treatment: Levodopa + Carbidopa
  • Long-term levodopa use → wearing-off, on-off phenomena, and dyskinesia
  • Advanced therapies are used when medications no longer control symptoms effectively
  • Restorative therapies (like adrenal medullary transplants) are experimental and rarely used now

Key Takeaway:

When Parkinson's patients become refractory to medication, DBS, targeted lesioning, and focused ultrasound are viable advanced therapeutic options.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with Parkinson's disease has resting tremors (4-6 Hz), bradykinesia, and mask-like facies. What is the probable cause of the tremor?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The resting tremor in Parkinson's disease is primarily due to disinhibition of thalamic neurons, which then exhibit intrinsic autorhythmic firing patterns.
  • This results from abnormal basal ganglia output following degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra.
  • These tremors are:
    • Typically 4-6 Hz
    • Appear at rest
    • Diminish with voluntary movement or sleep.
  • While imbalance of neurotransmitters like dopamine and acetylcholine contributes to rigidity and bradykinesia, the tremor itself is specifically linked to thalamic rhythmicity rather than cerebellar dysfunction or GABAergic neuron degeneration.

Explanation of other options:

Imbalance between excitatory and inhibitory neurotransmitters (Option B): An imbalance between excitatory (e.g., glutamate) and inhibitory (e.g., dopamine, GABA) neurotransmitters contributes to rigidity and bradykinesia in Parkinson's, but the resting tremor is primarily driven by thalamic autorhythmicity.

Failure of the damping action of the cerebellum (Option C): Leads to intention tremor, not resting tremor.

Degeneration of GABAergic neurons in the striatum (Option D): Occurs in Huntington's disease, associated with chorea.
